column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=While Tim Berners-Lee was n't enthusiastic about it , you called for the first International WWW conference .
#Text=How did those conferences shape the WWW ?
#Text=The conferences still run , the 2007 one was in Banff .
#Text=They are an occasion to meet and work very hard for a few days at the exchange of ideas .
#Text=The papers of the presentations are published in well-known academic journals .
#Text=That incites people to prepare well and present to colleagues .
#Text=Many web technologies started at one of the conferences ( proxies , VRML , ... )
#Text=Working groups are established there .
#Text=Because many want to go but can do so only when funded by their institute or company , it often means they have to present a paper .
#Text=Vague ideas are then consolidated and cast into programming code , which otherwise might not happen .
#Text=In addition the Conference Committee soon convinced the Web Consortium to hold one of its annual meetings in conjunction with the conference .
#Text=I am no longer involved with this , but at least during the years 1996 to 2004 this synergy was present and a track of the conference was devoted to the work of the Consortium .
#Text=Therefore Tim was also present every year .
#Text=I always saw the Consortium as the " church " with Tim as the " pope " .
#Text=In the Consortium there is a set of rules for arriving at decisions after which everyone has to abide by them .
#Text=There are industrial and sometimes political stakes .
#Text=The Conferences
#Text=however , as long as I was member of the Committee , I saw as the " state " of " laymen " ; you had freedom of expression and could propose the most wild schemes .
#Text=Between church and state
#Text=I prefer a complete separation .

#Text=That did not mean of course that we did not collaborate closely between Consortium and Conference Committee : there always was a delegate of the Consortium member of the Committee although that was not a requirement .
#Text=We wanted both to be successful .
#Text=Related to that , I have been told the WWW was initially to run on micropayments .
#Text=Who had that idea , and why do you believe it never came about ?
#Text=It never was in the original goals to use micropayments .
#Text=However , for keynote speaker of the first conference ( May 1994 ) I had invited David Schaum , an expert in digital money .
#Text=I was therefore already then convinced of the need for digital money : payment with guaranteed value but not traceable origin .
#Text=We still do not have anything like that .
#Text=To me a much more important reason to introduce digital money than untraceability is a free market for information .
#Text=The ideas of digital payments were targeting sales of goods and payment of subscriptions .
#Text=To me it is more important to break the vicious triangle of author-reader-advertiser .
#Text=In the beginning I was often completely misunderstood .
#Text=There were even newspaper articles that led to hate-mail through incomprehension .
